courseTitle: The Effect of Gravity on Plant Development

pageData.titleName2: The Effect of Gravity on Plant Development

pageData.text: Plants use Earth’s gravity to correctly orient their roots and shoots after seed germination, which is called <button class='glossary-text'>gravitropism</button>. In this lab, students will change the orientation of germinating seeds to see the effects gravity has on their direction of growth.

pageData.text: One of the biggest obstacles to long-term human space exploration and our possible colonization of other planets is the ability to feed the astronauts on these missions. Food is very heavy and therefore energy intensive to transport and store; furthermore, any food contamination or shortage risks the life of the crew. The most obvious solution is for astronauts to grow their own food while in space, but to do that, scientists must first understand how to grow plants in zero-gravity conditions.  Since plants have evolved under Earth’s gravity, much of their growth and processes (like water and nutrient transport) are dependent on gravity.

Astronauts have been growing plants on the International Space Station (ISS) to study these effects and in 2015 ate the first lettuce successfully grown in space<sup>1</sup>. Other Earth-based experiments have simulated the lower gravities of the Moon and Mars to study how plants might grow in those environments. These studies are also exploring the effects of other factors associated with space travel, such as the impacts of space radiation on plant growth and food safety.

1Rainey, K. (2015, August 7). Crew members sample leafy greens grown on Space Station. NASA.
https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/research/news/meals_ready_to_eat

pageData.text: Plant growth is polarized; roots grow into the soil, and photosynthetic tissues grow away from the soil and toward sunlight. Plant seeds become buried in the ground in all possible orientations. Germinating seedlings require a mechanism to correctly orient their growth. In the absence of barriers, plant growth is directional, so that in most plants, roots grow downward and shoots and leaves grow upward. This process is called <button class='glossary-text'>gravitropism</button> or <button class='glossary-text'>geotropism</button>. We can clearly observe the effects of gravitropism when we plant seeds. No matter the direction the seed is planted, the root will always grow downward and the shoot will grow upward. <button class='glossary-text'>Positive gravitropism</button> indicates plant growth toward the direction of gravity (e.g., roots grow downward), whereas <button class='glossary-text'>negative gravitropism</button> indicates plant growth away from the direction of gravity (e.g., shoots and leaves grow upward).

In plants, active cell duplication occurs in specialized regions called the meristem. In germinating seedlings, roots grow from an area called the <button class='glossary-text'>root apical meristem</button>, also known as the zone of cell division, which is located at the end of the embryonic hypocotyl, or the stem of the plant. The tissue from which the root grows is called the <button class='glossary-text'>radicle</button>. Cells in the root apical meristem are small and undifferentiated. As the root begins to grow, the root apical meristem maintains a position just behind the root tip (called the root cap). The root cap protects the meristem cells as the root pushes through the soil. Root cap cells are subjected to considerable abrasion and stress forces; they do not survive for a long time and have to be renewed continuously. Directly behind the apical meristem is the <button class='glossary-text'>zone of elongation</button>. This cell elongation drives root growth. Adjacent to the zone of cell elongation is the <button class='glossary-text'>zone of maturation</button> or <button class='glossary-text'>zone of differentiation</button>. Figure 1 shows the anatomy of a root tip.

pageData.text: Gravity does not change the cell division pattern in the meristem, but it does change the cell elongation pattern. Roots grow downward in response to gravity. If the <button class='glossary-text'>root apical meristem</button> happens to be oriented at the top of a germinating seed, the root will bend and curve downward. This is achieved by modulating cell length in the zone of cell elongation. Cells on the side facing downward elongate less than cells on the side facing upward. This causes the root to curve and grow downward toward the direction of gravity.

Shoots grow in a similar way to roots. The tissue from which the shoot grows is called the <button class='glossary-text'>plumule</button>. Germinating seeds have a <button class='glossary-text'>shoot apical meristem</button> located near the <button class='glossary-text'>cotyledons</button> (seed leaves). The shoot apical meristem is the location of active cell division in the stem, and a zone of cell elongation is located next to the shoot apical meristem. Gravity has the opposite effect on elongating cells in the shoot than what it had in the root. Cells on the side facing downward elongate more than cells on the side facing upward. This causes the shoot to curve and grow upward away from the direction of gravity.

When cell elongation and cell differentiation are complete, the tissue orientation is fixed and will not change in response to changes in the direction of gravity. If a plant is repositioned from a vertical to a horizontal orientation, only the newly developing cells will respond to the perceived change in gravity and orient themselves with respect to the new gravitational direction. Therefore, only the new cells produced by the root and <button class='glossary-text'>shoot apical meristem</button>s will grow away from (shoots) or toward (roots) the direction of gravity.

In this activity, lettuce seeds will be used to examine the effects of gravity on plant development. Rotating growing seeds at different rates over several days will produce varying results as plants adjust to the changing direction of gravity.

Read through the activity.
Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize the work area.
Place a piece of notebook/printer paper into the plastic container. Saturate the paper with tap water using the transfer pipet, and drain off any excess water.
Place approximately 150 seeds on the moistened piece of paper, making sure to evenly space out the seeds. Seal the plastic container with the airtight lid.
Place the container under the grow light.

Wait 5–8 days until the seeds have germinated. This will be apparent when the seed coat splits open and a short root and shoot (a little sprout) can be seen emerging from the seed. Begin the experiment shortly after seed coat splits and root and shoot appear. Waiting too long can negatively impact the activity.

Check the container a few times per day to make sure that the germinating seeds do not dry out. If any appear dry, use the transfer pipet to moisten the paper. Make sure to reseal the container with the airtight lid after this process.

In Activity 1, you will grow germinated lettuce seeds in Petri dishes in various orientations over 4 days and observe root and shoot growth. During this time, some of the dishes will be rotated at different speeds to observe the effect of gravity on root and shoot growth.
Place a piece of filter paper into each of the 4 Petri dishes.

Using the grease pencil, mark the filters in the dishes as follows:
  • Control
  • No rotation
  • Slow rotation
  • Fast rotation
Fill the beaker with tap water.
Use the transfer pipet to wet each piece of filter paper to saturation with the tap water.
Drain any excess water from the Petri dishes.

From the plastic container, carefully place 25–30 germinated seedlings in each of the Petri dishes on the saturated filter papers. Use forceps to gently transfer the seedlings. Place the germinated seedlings so that they are spaced out evenly and oriented so that all shoots and roots point in the same direction. Seal each Petri dish along the edge with a strip of water-resistant tape.
Place the Petri dish marked Control on a flat surface.
Use the large binder clips to clamp the Petri dishes as shown in Figure 2. Make sure the Petri dishes are stable when placed in a vertical position

pageData.text: Place the other Petri dishes into the remaining binder clips. Draw a horizontal line on each Petri dish lid to mark the horizontal orientation of the seedlings.
Leave the Petri dish marked No rotation in the same position during Days 1–3.
Rotate the dish marked Slow rotation by 45° each morning. On Day 4, the dish should be positioned so that all seedlings are almost in the same horizontal orientation as they were on Day 1.
Rotate the dish marked Fast rotation two or three times each day, by 45° for each rotation. Try to evenly space the intervals between rotations as best as possible.
During this 4-day process, if any of the filter papers start becoming dry, use the transfer pipet to moisten the paper. Do not let them dry out.

Place all the Petri dishes on a table for observation. Note the direction of root and shoot growth in each dish, and compare these directions with the horizontal lines marked in Activity 1A Step 9 on Day 1. Measure the degree of root and shoot curvature for every seedling in each dish using the protractor. Draw a horizontal centerline across the Petri dish lid for each seedling, and use this for taking the measurements. Measure how far away from the centerline the roots and shoots are.
Record these results in Data Table 1. Take a photograph of each Petri dish to document the results.

data.title: Gravitropism (geotropism)
data.content: The process of a plant root or shoot involuntary orienting itself based on gravity as the stimulus

data.title: Negative gravitropism
data.content: Plant growth away from the direction of gravity (shoots grow upward)

data.title: Plumule
data.content: The tissue from which a plant shoot grows

data.title: Positive gravitropism
data.content: Plant growth toward the direction of gravity (roots grow downward)

data.title: Radicle
data.content: The tissue from which a plant root grows

data.title: Root apical meristem
data.content: The location of root growth; also referred to as the zone of cell division

data.title: Shoot apical meristem
data.content: The location of shoot growth; also referred to as the zone of cell division

data.title: Zone of elongation
data.content: The area behind the apical meristem that drives plant growth in roots and shoots

data.title: Zone of maturation
data.content: The area of the growing root/shoot where elongating cells complete their differentiation
